body:
This is a bug in Sympy, can you file one there?

On Wed, Sep 25, 2013 at 9:39 AM, andjoely notifications@github.com wrote:

> I find it useful to render to results of sympy computations as images
> rather than mathjax because large equations rendered in mathjax make the
> notebook very slow. To accomplish this, I can execute:
> 
> import sympy as symfrom IPython.display import Latex, display, display_latexfrom sympy.interactive import printingprinting.init_printing(use_latex='png')sym.var('alpha,eta')display(alpha**2 + eta)
> 
> This correctly prints the math expression rendered as an image.
> 
> However after doing init_printing as above, I am now unable to display
> latex strings:
> 
> from IPython.display import Latex, display, display_latexfrom sympy.interactive import printingprinting.init_printing(use_latex='png')display(Latex('$\alpha^2 + \eta$'))
> 
> This just displays the string repr:
> 
> If I change display to display_latex it will just return None and not
> display anything
> 
> But if I change the use_latex keyword arg to 'mathjax' the above will work
> with either display or display_latex.
> 
> I made a workaround function for my specific needs using IPython.lib.latex
> allowing for selecting backends for latex display between matplotlib,
> dvipng, and mathjax. There should be a way to display both latex text and
> objects representable as latex with the display function using a variety of
> easily configurable backends for rendering the latex.
> 
> Additionally, when latex is rendered as an image in the html notebook,
> using nbconvert to convert to pdf should re-render the latex if possible. I
> have not tested whether that is already done with displaying sympy objects
> as png using IPython.display.display but my workaround function does not do
> 
> ## it.
> 
> System Info below:
> 
> {'codename': 'An Afternoon Hack',
>  'commit_hash': '7c2ea3a',
>  'commit_source': 'installation',
>  'default_encoding': 'cp1252',
>  'ipython_path': 'C:\WinPython-64bit\python-2.7.5.amd64\lib\site-packages\IPython',
>  'ipython_version': '1.1.0',
>  'os_name': 'nt',
>  'platform': 'Windows-7-6.1.7601-SP1',
>  'sys_executable': 'C:\WinPython-64bit\python-2.7.5.amd64\python.exe',
>  'sys_platform': 'win32',
>  'sys_version': '2.7.5 (default, May 15 2013, 22:44:16) [MSC v.1500 64 bit (AMD64)]'}
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/4275
> .

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

They are setting `ip.display_formatter.formatters['text/latex'].enabled = False`, to disable _all_ latex output.  You can revert this with `ip.display_formatter.formatters['text/latex'].enabled = True`.

I plan on opening a SymPy PR to fix how they are managing the display
logic...

On Wed, Sep 25, 2013 at 10:27 AM, Min RK notifications@github.com wrote:

> They are setting ip.display_formatter.formatters['text/latex'].enabled =
> False, to disable _all_ latex output. You can revert this with ip.display_formatter.formatters['text/latex'].enabled
> = True.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/4275#issuecomment-25107405
> .

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com
Closing as this is a sympy issue.

Note: `ip` in the above example is:

```
import IPython
ip = IPython.core.getipython.get_ipython()
```
